abstract: The effect of machining on stress corrosion crack initiation of annealed Type 316L stainless steel was investigated through accelerated testing in high-temperature hydrogenated water. It was observed that stress corrosion cracks only initiated on machined surfaces with machining marks perpendicular to the loading direction and a porous inner oxide layer was identified as an important factor contributing to crack initiation. Furthermore, most cracks stopped within the machining-induced near-surface ultrafine-grained layer and the machining-induced residual stresses did not appear to have a significant effect on crack initiation. A correlation between crack initiation and the surface/near-surface features is identified and discussed.

author_highlights.sentence: Machining promoted SCC in annealed 316SS in high temperature water.
SCC initiation was associated with machining marks and did not occur for polished surfaces.
A porous inner oxide layer was a major factor affecting SCC initiation on the machined surface.
Machining-induced residual stress did not markedly affect on SCC initiation under SSRT conditions.
Optimized machining parameters that improved productivity and SCC resistance were identified.

body_text.sentence: The cracks observed in the cross-section samples were classified into four categories: i) cracks within the inner oxide layer that did not penetrate into the material, which were observed in both the machined and OPS polished surfaces, (Fig. 9(a)); ii) cracks that penetrated into the material but stopped in the ultrafine-grained region, (Fig. 9(b)); iii) cracks that stopped at the interface between the ultrafine-grained layer and the deformed region, (Fig. 9(c)); and iv) cracks that penetrated into and stopped within the deformed region, (Fig. 9(d, e)).
